abstract: The Gede Volcanic Complex (GVC) of the Sunda island arc (West Java, Indonesia) consists of multiple volcanic centres and eruptive groups with complex magmatic histories. We present new petrological, mineralogical, whole-rock major and trace element and Sr–O isotopic data to provide constraints on the relative importance of fractional crystallisation and magma mixing in petrogenesis, as well as on the role and nature of the arc crust. Banded juvenile scoria from Young and Old Gede provide unequivocal evidence for the (late-stage) interaction of distinct magmas at Gede volcano. However, the relatively small-degree compositional zoning observed in plagioclase phenocrysts of all eruptive groups (up to ~20 mol% An) may be attributed to physical changes in magma properties (e.g. P, T, and PH2O) rather than changes in melt composition. Major element and trace element variations within each eruptive series are inconsistent with magmatic evolution through simple mixing processes. Instead, mixing of variably fractionated magma batches is suggested to account for the significant scatter in some element variation diagrams. No correlation is observed between textural complexity and/or mineral disequilibrium and whole-rock geochemistry. REE data and geochemical modelling indicate that fractional crystallisation involving amphibole in the mid- to lower crust, and fractionation of plagioclase, clinopyroxene, Fe–Ti oxide ± olivine ± orthopyroxene provide strong control on the geochemical evolution of GVC rocks. Two-pyroxene geothermobarometry provides pre-eruption crystallisation temperatures of 891–1,046°C and pressures of 3.4–6.5 kbar, equivalent to ~13–24 km depth beneath the volcanoes (mid- to lower crust). Low, mantle-like clinopyroxene δ18O values of GVC lavas and poor correlation of Sr isotope ratios with indices of differentiation precludes significant assimilation of isotopically distinct crust during magmatic differentiation. Therefore, we suggest that the geochemical character of the moderately thick West Javan arc crust is relatively immature compared to typical continental crust. Trace element ratios and strontium isotopes show that the magmatic source composition of the older geographical units, Gegerbentang and Older Quaternary, is distinct from the other GVC groups. \u

Abstract 1 
The Gede Volcanic Complex (GVC) of the Sunda island arc (West Java, Indonesia) consists 2 
of multiple volcanic centres and eruptive groups with complex magmatic histories. We 3 
present new petrological, mineralogical, whole-rock major and trace element, and Sr-O 4 
isotopic data to provide constraints on the relative importance of fractional crystallisation and 5 
magma mixing in petrogenesis, as well as on the role and nature of the arc crust. Banded 6 
juvenile scoria from Young and Old Gede provide unequivocal evidence for the (late-stage) 7 
interaction of distinct magmas at Gede volcano. However, the relatively small-degree 8 
compositional zoning observed in plagioclase phenocrysts of all eruptive groups (up to ~20 9 
mol% An) may be attributed to physical changes in magma properties (e.g. P, T, and PH2O) 10 
rather than changes in melt composition. Major element and trace element variations within 11 
each eruptive series are inconsistent with magmatic evolution through simple mixing 12 
processes. Instead, mixing of variably fractionated magma batches is suggested to account for 13 
the significant scatter in some element variation diagrams. No correlation is observed 14 
between textural complexity and/or mineral disequilibrium and whole-rock geochemistry. 15 
REE data and geochemical modelling indicate that fractional crystallisation involving 16 
amphibole in the mid- to lower crust, and fractionation of plagioclase, clinopyroxene, Fe-Ti 17 
oxide ± olivine ± orthopyroxene provide strong control on the geochemical evolution of GVC 18 
rocks. Two-pyroxene geothermobarometry provides pre-eruption crystallisation temperatures 19 
of 891-1046ºC and pressures of 3.4-6.5 kbar, equivalent to ~13-24km depth beneath the 20 
volcanoes (mid- to lower crust). Low, mantle-like clinopyroxene 18O values of GVC lavas 21 
and poor correlation of Sr isotope ratios with indices of differentiation precludes significant 22 
assimilation of isotopically distinct crust during magmatic differentiation. Therefore, we 23 
suggest that the geochemical character of the moderately thick West Javan arc crust is 24 
relatively immature compared to typical continental crust. Trace element ratios and strontium 25 
isotopes show that the magmatic source composition of the older geographical units, 26 
Gegerbentang and Older Quaternary, is distinct from the other GVC groups. 27

 3 
Arc lavas display a wide variation in composition, which reflects both the composition of the 1 
primary magma from which they originated and the multitude of differentiation processes 2 
magmas experience en route to the Earth‟s surface. Among the latter processes, fractional 3 
crystallisation (Ewart 1982; Foden 1983; Gerbe et al. 1992), crustal contamination (Davidson 4 
et al. 1987; Hildreth and Moorbath 1988; Davidson and Harmon 1989) and magma mixing 5 
(Gamble et al. 1999; Tepley et al. 2000) are commonly called upon to explain geochemical 6 
variation in arc lavas. Constraints upon the relative importance of differentiation processes at 7 
individual volcanoes are essential before the characteristics of the source can be investigated. 8 
The Sunda arc, formed by subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate beneath the 9 
Eurasian Plate, includes around 80% of Indonesia‟s active volcanoes - many of which have 10 
produced eruptions that have had significant impact on local and global environments (e.g. 11 
Toba, Krakatau and Tambora). However, despite an apparently simple tectonic setting, 12 
understanding magma genesis and evolution at the Sunda arc is complicated by along-arc 13 
changes in the composition and thickness of the overriding Eurasian plate (Hamilton 1979).  14 
GVC in West Java has been largely overlooked by petrologists and geochemists 15 
studying petrogenesis of Sunda arc volcanoes. This is surprising considering the active Gede 16 
Volcano (from which the complex derives its name) is one of the most prominent in West 17 
Java and is located in close proximity (~70 km) to the densely populated capital, Jakarta. 18 
Furthermore, to the east of GVC researchers have argued that the dominant crustal 19 
component identified in magma genesis is provided by the subducting slab (i.e. source 20 
contamination) (Edwards 1990; Gerbe et al. 1992; Turner and Foden 2001; Gertisser and 21 
Keller 2003; Handley et al. 2007; cf. Chadwick et al. 2007), while to the west of GVC, He 22 
(Gasparon and Varne 1998), Nd (Turner and Foden 2001) and Sr (Handley et al. 2008a) 23 
isotopic investigations reveal the importance of shallow-level crustal contamination. 24 
Therefore, GVC is in an ideal location to investigate contributions from the arc crust in 25 
volcanic petrogenesis and conclusions from this study will help elucidate the nature of the 26 
local arc crust. This paper presents new data on the petrography, mineralogy, geochemistry 27 
and Sr-O isotopic composition of GVC volcanic products. Textural and chemical information 28 
of phenocrysts is integrated with major, trace element and isotopic data to provide constraints 29 
on the relative roles of fractional crystallisation and magma mixing, as well as the role and 30 
possible nature of the arc crust. These questions are fundamental to understanding the 31 
functioning of magmatic systems. 32

Geological setting 1 
GVC is located in West Java within the Quaternary volcanic front of the Sunda arc (Fig. 1 2 
inset). The Sunda arc forms the western part of the Indonesian subduction zone system and 3 
formed as a result of the northward subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate beneath the 4 
Eurasian Plate. A detailed tectonic description of the area is given by Hamilton (1979). GVC 5 
is dominated by the twin stratovolcanoes of Gede (2958 m), the only active volcano of the 6 
complex, and Pangrango (3019 m), an extinct volcano to the northwest (Fig. 1). Gede is 7 
divided morphologically and stratigraphically into Old and Young Gede (Situmorang and 8 
Hadisantono 1992). The remnant crater rim (50-200m high) of Old Gede is marked by 9 
Gunung Gumuruh (Fig. 1). This crater, now truncated by Young Gede in the north-west, is 10 
the largest (~1600m in diameter) and oldest crater at Gede. The volcanic deposits of Old 11 
Gede are exposed on the south-eastern slope of Gede and form a deeply dissected 12 
morphology. Young Gede consists of several smaller craters (Sela, Ratu, Lanang, Wadon and 13 
Baru) contained within the 1km wide, steep-walled (200m) Gede crater. Most of the eruptive 14 
deposits of Young Gede are confined in relatively narrow belts, extending north-east and 15 
south-west of the summit due to the topographic highs of Pangrango-Masigit and Old Gede in 16 
the northwest and southeast, respectively. The heavily forested Pangrango volcano is 17 
constructed on the north-east rim of a large caldera/collapse structure (Gunung Masigit, Fig. 18 
1) which is open to the south-west. The Gegerbentang Complex consists of a series of eroded 19 
volcanoes situated to the north of Gede and is relatively older than both Gede and Pangrango 20 
(Fig. 1). The oldest deposits of Quaternary volcanic material (Older Quaternary Volcanic 21 
group) are exposed to the east and south west of Gede (Besar and Koncana respectively, Fig. 22 
1). Basement rocks of the complex and surrounding area are dominated by Tertiary aged 23 
volcanogenic and marine sediments (Effendi et al. 1998). Around 20 small eruptions of short 24 
duration have been reported from Gede volcano since the mid-18th century. Pyroclastic flows 25 
were generated during a larger eruption in 1840. More recently, a brief ash ejection occurred 26 
in 1957 (VSI) and at the end of April 1991 a series of volcanic earthquake swarms were 27 
recorded (VSI). Kawah Lanang and Kawah Wadon are the most active craters at present, 28 
showing signs of hydrothermal activity. 29

The diverse range of volcanic rocks and volcanic related products from the GVC include: 32 
lava, pyroclastic flow, air fall, debris flow and lahar deposits. Sample material collected for 33

pyroclastic flow deposits. The generally low LOI values for most samples (Table 1) and lack 2 
of visible alteration in rock samples and thin sections (except in a few specimens) confirm the 3 
samples are fresh. In this study the eruptive products of Young Gede are grouped into Young 4 
Gede Kawah Ratu (those sourced from Kawah Ratu) and Young Gede Other Vents (sourced 5

(Situmorang and Hadisantono 1992). Here the term Pangrango refers to all units of the 8

Gegerbentang complex. The relative stratigraphy of the volcanic centres and eruptive groups 10 
is shown on the inset diagram in Fig. 1. On the basis of Ba/La and Zr/Nb trace element ratios 11

Results 17 
Petrography 18 
The volcanic products of GVC have not been previously described. Therefore, this section 19 
will focus on the petrography and mineralogy of each eruptive centre (in stratigraphical order 20 
from the youngest to oldest) highlighting textural features which may contribute to the 21 
understanding of petrogenesis at GVC. Basaltic andesite is the most common rock type 22 
erupted and basalts are largely restricted to eruptives of Pangrango and Gegerbentang. The 23 
majority of GVC rocks contain similar mineral assemblages of plagioclase, clinopyroxene 24 
and Fe-Ti oxide ± orthopyroxene ± olivine. Petrographic summaries of Gede lavas are given 25 
in Supplementary Table 1 and mineral data are found in Supplementary Tables 2-6. 26 
Volcanic rocks from the Kawah Ratu centre of Young Gede (YGKR) consist of 27 
basaltic andesites and andesites and contain a mineral assemblage of plagioclase, 28 
clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene and Ti-magnetite, set within a very fine-grained groundmass of 29 
plagioclase, Fe-Ti oxide and devitrified glass. The Kawah Ratu eruptives are dominantly 30 
seriate in texture and contain the most textural complexity of all groups. Oscillatory zoning, 31 
sieve textures and concentric bands of melt inclusions are observed in a large number of 32

plagioclase phenocrysts and microphenocrysts. More than half of the samples of this group 1 
contain anhedral orthopyroxene phenocrysts mantled by clinopyroxene. 2 
Rocks erupted from the Other Vents Group at Young Gede are dominated by basaltic 3 
andesites, with minor andesites and contain an identical mineral assemblage to the Kawah 4 
Ratu rocks, with the exception of olivine instead of orthopyroxene phenocrysts in a few 5 
basaltic andesite samples. Rocks of this group display mainly porphyritic textures and are 6 
generally less phenocryst rich than Kawah Ratu volcanic rocks and the plagioclase 7 
phenocrysts are texturally less complex. Many of the rocks sampled of this group are highly 8 
vesicular juvenile scoria of pyroclastic flow deposits, which contain a very fine-grained 9 
groundmass of devitrified glass and plagioclase, or plagioclase, oxide and pyroxene. These 10 
samples show evidence of magma mingling between dark, less evolved material and lighter 11 
more evolved material (described in more detail below). Xenoliths of igneous origin are 12 
present in some Young Gede samples (see below). 13 
The basaltic andesites and andesites of Old Gede are dominantly porphyritic to seriate 14 
in texture. In the basaltic andesites, plagioclase, clinopyroxene and titanomagnetite are 15 
accompanied either by olivine, orthopyroxene or in a few cases both (suggestive of mineral 16 
disequilibrium). Olivine is not present in the andesites. The volcanic products of Old Gede 17 
contain lower modal abundances of ferromagnesian minerals compared to those of Young 18 
Gede (Supplementary Table 1). The very fine- to fine-grained groundmass contains 19 
plagioclase and oxide ± pyroxene. Magma mingling textures are also observed in juvenile 20 
scoria of pyroclastic flow deposits of this group (see below). 21 
Eruptives from Pangrango consist of basalts and basaltic andesites. Most of these 22 
lavas are strikingly porphyritic in hand specimen, containing large (up to ~1.2 cm) euhedral 23 
clinopyroxene phenocrysts. The rocks are seriate in texture and mineral assemblages 24 
comprise plagioclase, clinopyroxene, Ti-magnetite with either olivine (in the basalts) or 25 
orthopyroxene (in the basaltic andesites). The phenocrysts are set in a fine-grained 26 
groundmass of plagioclase, clinopyroxene ± olivine. Some of the orthopyroxene phenocrysts 27 
are mantled by clinopyroxene. 28 
Most rocks from Gegerbentang display seriate textures of plagioclase, clinopyroxene, 29 
orthopyroxene, with minor Ti-magnetite and rare olivine, in a very fine-, to fine-grained 30 
groundmass of plagioclase and oxide ± pyroxene. 31 
It has proved difficult to obtain fresh samples from the Older Quaternary units; 32 
chlorite is commonly observed replacing ferromagnesian minerals in these rocks and LOI 33 
values are generally higher than those of other GVC rocks (0.35-0.91 wt%, Table 1). The 34

 4 
Mineral characteristics and chemistry 5 
Plagioclase 6 
Subhedral to euhedral plagioclase dominates the modal phase assemblage of all GVC rocks. 7 
Oscillatory zoning, sieve textures and concentric bands of melt inclusions are present in a 8 
large number of phenocrysts within all groups but particularly within Kawah Ratu rocks    9 
suggesting complex histories of these phenocrysts. In some Kawah Ratu samples, sieve-10 
textured phenocryst cores are surrounded by clear rims of plagioclase. A large number of 11 
plagioclase phenocrysts in Young Gede and Old Gede rocks have irregular/patchy, pale 12 
brown, isotropic glass inclusions. Resorbed cores are present in occasional plagioclase 13 
phenocrysts from Pangrango and Kawah Ratu. 14 
Plagioclase phenocrysts of GVC rocks display a broad range in composition from 15 
~An45-An95 and are displayed in Figs. 3a-c. In the Young Gede Kawah Ratu rocks, 16 
compositions are more restricted in the basaltic andesites (An68-86) than in the andesites (An49-17 
83, Figs. 3b and c, respectively), which display highly variable core, mid and rim anorthite 18 
contents. Plagioclase phenocrysts and groundmass An compositions in the basaltic andesites 19 
of the Young Gede Other Vents group display an extremely restricted range and are 20 
noticeably higher than those in other GVC groups (above 81 mol% with the exception of one 21 
rim sample, Fig. 3b), including the basalts from Pangrango (Fig. 3a). Plagioclase cores of the 22 
andesites lie within the range of basaltic andesite plagioclase cores of the Young Gede Other 23 
Vents group. However, mid and rim compositions extend to significantly lower Anorthite 24 
content (An44). Plagioclase compositions cover a relatively broad range in both the basaltic 25 
andesite and andesites of Old Gede (Figs. 3b and c). Rim analyses of plagioclase in the 26

Clinopyroxene 12 
Clinopyroxene (augite) is the most abundant ferromagnesian mineral (by modal volume) in 13 
GVC rocks, found in all samples accompanied by either olivine or orthopyroxene and very 14 
occasionally both (indicating mineral disequilibrium in the latter case). Phenocrysts are 15 
typically subhedral to euhedral and most exhibit simple twining, although oscillatory zoning 16 
is observed in some crystals. The phenocrysts display a broad range in size from 17 
microphenocryst to ~1.2 cm. Large (0.5-1.2cm) phenocrysts are characteristic of the 18 
Pangrango basalts. Clinopyroxene phenocrysts of slightly smaller dimensions are featured in 19 
the volcanic products of Gegerbentang. Several clinopyroxene phenocrysts of the Young 20 
Gede Other Vent group contain anhedral glass inclusions, similar to those seen in plagioclase 21 
phenocrysts of the same group. 22 
 Most of the eruptive groups display a fairly restricted range in clinopyroxene 23 
composition (Figs. 4a-i). The basaltic andesites of the Young Gede Other Vent group display 24 
the greatest within-group variation (En38-45Wo38-45Fs12-20, Fig. 4c) and contrast with the 25 
highly restricted range in plagioclase composition observed in this group (Fig. 3b). The 26 
Pangrango basalts do not possess the most Ca-rich or Fe-poor clinopyroxene compositions, as 27 
might be expected in the least evolved (lowest SiO2) rocks analysed from GVC (Fig. 4f). 28 
Pigeonite (En55Wo25Fs20) was present in a 4 mm glomerocryst/cumulate xenolith in an Older 29 
Quaternary Volcanic group lava (Fig. 4i). 30

Olivine 20 
Olivine displays a limited presence in GVC volcanic rocks, restricted to a small number of 21 
basalts and basaltic andesites. The anhedral and occasionally embayed olivine phenocrysts 22 
are typically smaller than pyroxene and plagioclase phenocrysts within the same samples 23 
from the Young Gede Other Vents group. In one sample from Old Gede (G07) olivine is the 24 
dominant ferromagnesian phase (Supplementary Table 1) and occurs as large subhedral 25 
crystals. In other Old Gede samples olivine phenocrysts are small, anhedral and co-exist with 26 
orthopyroxene. Olivine is a major component of the ferromagnesian mineral assemblage in 27 
basalts from Pangrango, constituting ~8-12 % of the modal volume.  Most crystals are small, 28 
commonly with rounded edges, and sometimes occur as inclusions within clinopyroxene. 29 
Olivine is only observed in one sample from Gegerbentang, characterised by small anhedral 30 
phenocrysts, some showing evidence of resorption. 31 
 Olivine compositions are displayed in Fig. 5. Forsterite (Fo) contents of olivines in 32 
basaltic andesites of the Young Gede Other Vent group (Fo70-72) are higher than Fo contents 33 
in any other GVC group, consistent with the high (most primitive) An contents of plagioclase 34

Fe-Ti oxide 4 
Fe-Ti oxide (titanomagnetite) occurs as phenocrysts, inclusions within ferromagnesian 5 
minerals (dominantly clinopyroxene) and as a groundmass phase in most GVC rocks. 6 
Titanomagnetite is typically subhedral and constitutes a small percentage of the modal rock 7 
volume (~1-3%). Subhedral titanomagnetite phenocrysts are relatively more abundant in the 8 
Older Quaternary Volcanic group compared with the majority of GVC rocks (Supplementary 9 
Table 1) and have higher than average Ti contents. Relatively high Ti contents are also 10 
observed in titanomagnetite phenocrysts in Pangrango lavas (Supplementary Table 6). 11 
 12 
Xenoliths 13 
Xenoliths are generally uncommon in GVC rocks. Angular clasts of igneous material ~1mm 14 
to 2cm in size are observed within the Young Gede Other Vents group, particularly within 15 
juvenile scoria of pyroclastic flow deposits (e.g. G51, G01A). The most abundant type 16 
consists of large plagioclase and orthopyroxene phenocrysts, within a fine- to medium-17 
grained groundmass of plagioclase, orthopyroxene and oxide. The holocrystalline clasts, 18 
display sharp contacts with the host rock and can be removed relatively easily from the host 19 
matrix. 20 
A different type of igneous xenolith, dominated by tabular plagioclase (with melt-21 
inclusions), amphibole and elongate pyroxene was found in G18 (Old Gede). The amphibole 22 
is heavily altered, especially at crystal edges where a thick rim of opaque oxide has formed. 23 
The contact between the host and the (0.5 x 0.8cm) xenolith is irregular and slightly diffuse.   24 
A cumulate xenolith was found within Pangrango sample G16. The oval-shaped 25 
cumulate is ~0.5cm in diameter and composed of relatively large, generally interlocking 26 
plagioclase and pyroxene (orthopyroxene and minor clinopyroxene) crystals, with minor 27 
interstitial pyroxene. There is no obvious reaction rim at the contact between the cumulate 28 
xenolith and the host lava. 29

Magma mingling 17 
Several juvenile scoria samples from pyroclastic flow deposit units of Young Gede (Kawah 18 
Ratu and Other Vents) and Old Gede show evidence for the mingling of distinct magmas. 19 
The vesicular juvenile scoria is composed of dark grey/black material with irregularly shaped 20 
lenses or bands of lighter, pale-grey material. The majority of juvenile scoria from Young 21 
Gede are composed of the dark component (Fig. 6a, G36B & G51), while the samples from 22 
Old Gede are variably banded with more equal shares of both light and dark layers (Fig. 6c, 23 
G13). The dark bands contain phenocrysts of sub- to euhedral plagioclase, clinopyroxene and 24 
titanomagnetite and anhedral to subhedral olivine. The lighter layers contain the same 25 
mineral assemblage but with orthopyroxene substituted for olivine. Both layers display 26 
porphyritic textures (Fig. 6e) and oscillatory zoning and sieve textures in plagioclase 27 
phenocrysts. The contact between the two layers is always irregular in detail (Fig. 6e) and 28 
ranges from sharp to diffuse, indicating that mixing may have occurred in some samples. The 29 
Young Gede juvenile scoria (G36B and G51) possess small, angular xenolith clasts 30 
(described above), which display sharp contacts with the host rock. 31 
Compositions of plagioclase and pyroxene phenocrysts in the light and dark layers of 32 
sample G51 are plotted in Fig. 6b. Anorthite contents of plagioclase in the dark layer are high 33 
and restricted between An80-90. Plagioclase compositions in the light layer of G51 overlap 34

Major element data 9 
Major element data are given in Table 2 and presented in Fig. 7. GVC rocks possess 10 
intermediate silica contents (~51-63 wt %). Low MgO contents in the basalts (~4-5 wt %) 11 
suggest that these samples are fractionated and do not represent primary basalts. Major 12 
element trends are similar for most of the Gede Complex groups (Figs. 7a-h); negative 13 
correlations against silica are displayed for Fe2O3, MgO, CaO and TiO2, and positive 14 
correlations are generally observed for K2O and Na2O. The data show considerable scatter for 15 
Al2O3 and P2O5 versus SiO2. Volcanic rocks of Young Gede (both groups) display the 16 
greatest range in silica content (52-62 wt %). The Young Gede Other Vents group cluster at 17 
~55 wt % SiO2 and display relatively poor correlations of major elements with SiO2. The 18 
Pangrango lavas are among the least evolved samples collected from the complex and 19 
possess the highest TiO2 contents, up to ~1.2 wt % (Fig. 7g). Eruptives of Gegerbentang 20 
cluster towards the lower silica end of the GVC array and possess slighter higher P2O5 21 
content compared to other GVC rocks of comparable silica content (Fig. 7h). 22 
 23 
Trace element geochemistry 24 
Variations of selected trace elements with SiO2 are presented in Fig. 8. GVC rocks display 25 
increases with increasing silica of most LILE (e.g. Ba (Fig. 8a), Rb and here including Th and 26 
U), LREE (e.g. La, Fig. 8b) and some HFSE (Zr and Hf, not shown). Nb exhibits a very poor 27 
positive correlation (Fig. 8d). Elements that behave compatibly in most arc magmas, such as 28 
vanadium and nickel display reasonable (Fig. 8e) to poor (Fig. 8c) negative correlations with 29 
SiO2 in GVC rocks. Ni contents are extremely low (~1-17ppm) in GVC rocks and further 30 
confirm their highly fractionated character. Y, Yb, Sr, Pb and Eu data display considerable 31 
scatter and remain essentially constant over the range in silica content (e.g. Figs. 8f-h). There 32 
is little distinction in trace element variations of the separate eruptive groups. 33

Discussion  4 
Differentiation of magma 5 
Fractional crystallisation 6 
The predominance of basaltic andesites, low MgO and extremely low Ni contents in basalts 7 
of the GVC indicate that the lavas erupted are significantly fractionated. To quantitatively test 8 
whether fractional crystallisation of the mineral assemblage observed in GVC rocks is 9 
accountable for the major element variations observed (Fig. 7), least squares modelling was 10 
employed. Because GVC includes several large volcanic centres, the aims of modelling are 2 11 
fold: 1) To determine whether fractional crystallisation can explain major element variation 12 
within each eruptive series. 2) To establish whether the eruptive series of Gede volcano 13 
(Young Gede Kawah Ratu, Young Gede Other Vents and Old Gede) may be genetically 14 
related by the process of fractional crystallisation. 15 
Least squares modelling of GVC major element data utilises the XLFRAC 16 
programme of Stormer and Nicholls (1978). Summaries of least squares modelling results are 17 
given in Table 5. Fractional crystallisation models from the least evolved (lowest SiO2) to the 18 
most evolved (highest SiO2) rocks within each eruptive group yield good to excellent results, 19 
with r2 values less than or equal to 0.1 (models 1-11, Table 5). These models suggest that 20 
within-group major element variation can be explained by the fractional crystallisation of 21 
plagioclase, clinopyroxene, Fe-Ti oxide, plus olivine or orthopyroxene from the most basic 22 
end-members within each eruptive group with a maximum degree of crystallisation of 50% 23 
(model 10). However, from the basic to evolved members of the Young Gede Other Vents 24 
group models requires the addition of 8.6% plagioclase during fractionation of 25 
clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene and oxide. 26 
 The second objective of least squares modelling is to see if major element variation 27 
between Gede volcano sub-units may be explained through crystal fractionation. Models 12-28 
14 show that excellent r2 values of <0.06 are obtained, especially in models using the most 29 
basic Old Gede sample as parent to the most evolved Young Gede Kawah Ratu and Other 30 
Centre lavas (models 12 and 13, r2 = 0.03). However, both of these models require the 31 
addition, rather than removal, of a small percentage of clinopyroxene. Using the mineral 32 
phase proportions given by model 10 (Table 5), fractionation curves from the least evolved 33

To test the conclusions of least squares analysis and investigate whether the 5 
concentrations of trace elements in GVC rocks are controlled by fractional crystallisation of 6 
the same mineral assemblage, forward modelling of trace element concentrations was 7 
conducted using the Rayleigh fractionation equation: Cl = CoF
(D-1)
, where Cl and Co represent 8 
the concentration of an element in the daughter and parental liquids respectively, F is the 9 
fraction of liquid remaining and D is the bulk distribution coefficient. The results and model 10 
parameters are given in Fig. 8. The fractionation curves produced (FC G23) show variable 11 
success in fitting the array of the GVC data. The best fits are observed for the incompatible 12 
elements Ba and La (e.g. Figs. 8a and b) and Nb (Fig. 8d). Acceptable results are noted for V. 13 
However, poor fits are observed for other elements. This is largely a consequence of the 14 
scatter in the data in Figs. 8c and f-h. 15 
Several models have proposed that the geochemical diversity exhibited by arc lavas is 16 
controlled by crystallisation in the mid- to lower crust and that phenocryst textural 17 
complexity is subsequently acquired in the upper crust (e.g. Hildreth and Moorbath 1988; 18 
Annen et al. 2006). Based on REE ratios, amphibole fractionation at depth (mid- to lower 19 
crust) is thought to exert major control on magmatic differentiation in arc volcanoes and at 20 
GVC (Davidson et al. 2007). Mid- to lower crustal crystallisation pressures calculated for 21 
GVC pyroxenes (Table 1) and the presence of an amphibole-bearing xenolith in an Old Gede 22 
lava (G18) give support for amphibole-involved fractionation at depth beneath the GVC. 23 
Recent work by Brophy (2008) suggests that mid- to upper crustal hornblende-bearing basalt 24 
fractionation will produce steadily increasing LREE abundances but constant and then 25 
decreasing HREE abundances, like those observed for GVC lavas in Figs. 8b and 8h. To 26 
investigate whether fractionation of amphibole better explains the major and trace element 27 
characteristics of GVC rocks, fractionation trends for amphibole (FC Amph) are plotted in 28 
Figs. 7 and 8. Overall, magmatic evolution by amphibole fractionation is no more acceptable 29 
for reproducing major (e.g. Figs. 7d, e and g) and trace element trends (Fig. 8) than the 30 
fractionating phase assemblage observed in the rocks (FC G23). For some elements, the GVC 31 
data lie between fractionation curves for amphibole and the observed mineral assemblage in 32 
the rock, suggesting that the data may be explained by a combination of both processes (e.g. 33 
Figs. 7a, c and g, and 8f and h). 34

Magma mixing  2 
Magma mixing is important in the evolution of many arc magmas (e.g. Eichelberger et al. 3 
2000; Tepley et al. 2000) and in magmatic evolution at volcanoes of the Sunda arc (Slamet, 4 
Reubi et al., 2003; Batur, Reubi and Nicholls 2004; Krakatau, Mandeville et al. 1996; 5 
Merapi, Camus et al. 2000). Mingled scoria in volcanic rocks of Young Gede and Old Gede 6 
provide unequivocal evidence for the interaction of distinct magmas at GVC (Fig. 6). The 7 
question then arises whether or not magma mixing imparts a recognisable influence or 8 
control on element concentrations? Petrographic features in GVC rocks such as reverse 9 
zoning, sieve textured and resorbed cores in plagioclase phenocrysts, variation in coexisting 10 
plagioclase core compositions, mantling of orthopyroxene by clinopyroxene and 11 
juxtaposition of olivine with orthopyroxene indicate that closed-system crystal fractionation 12 
may be an over-simplistic model for magmatic evolution at GVC. Furthermore, least squares 13 
modelling of major element data required the addition of plagioclase or clinopyroxene in 14 
some models (Table 5). However, minor zoning and resorption features in plagioclase are not 15 
strict evidence for magma mixing, such textures are likely to result from changes in P, T, and 16 
PH2O (e.g. Pearce and Kolisnik, 1990; Ginibre et al. 2002 and references therein). Similarly, 17 
sieve-textured plagioclase are commonly interpreted to be produced by magma mixing but 18 
experimental data have shown that these textures can also be produced by decompression or 19 
heating (Nelson and Montana 1992; Johannes et al. 1994). In most GVC rocks, the amplitude 20 
of An mol% variation observed in: 1) plagioclase cores of the same rock and, 2) reversely 21 
zoned plagioclase is small (within 20 mol% An, Fig. 3), obviating the necessity of magma 22 
mixing. Mantling of orthopyroxene by clinopyroxene in GVC rocks may result from an 23 
increase in temperature due to the influx of more primitive magma, but can also be created by 24 
convective self-mixing (Couch et al. 2001). Alternatively, mantled orthopyroxene may be 25 
antecrystic and entrained by the magma during transit to the surface. The Mg content of 26 
mantled orthopyroxenes in basaltic andesites of Young Gede lie among the highest Mg 27 
orthopyroxene compositions observed in the rocks (Figs. 4a and c). 28 
To help assess the extent to which magma mixing can account for the geochemical 29 
diversity of the lavas, an example mixing line (MM) is plotted on Figs. 7 and 8, between the 30 
least- and most evolved Young Gede Kawah Ratu rocks (G23-G39). Rocks of this group 31 
were chosen as they show the greatest textural complexity. For major elements (except TiO2 32 
and P2O5, Figs. 7g and h) and some trace elements (those showing incompatible behaviour 33 
during differentiation) the magma mixing (MM) and fractional crystallisation trends (FC 34

In plots of the form A/B versus 1/B, mixing is controlled by the concentration of the 6 
denominator in the ratio. Consequently, plots of this type provide a simple check to see if 7 
data are consistent with binary mixing as data should form a linear array (Vogel 1982; 8 
Langmuir et al. 1978). La and Nd concentrations increase with differentiation in GVC rocks 9 
(e.g. Fig. 8b) and so a plot of La/Nd versus 1/Nd should indicate whether or not the 10 
systematic variation with SiO2 is consistent with mixing. Fig. 11a shows poor linearity within 11 
each eruptive group and within the GVC data as a whole and is, therefore, inconsistent with 12 
simple mixing processes. The solid lines labelled 1, 2 and 3 in Fig. 11a show several mixing 13 
trends between members of the same stratigraphical group (see figure caption for details) to 14 
give examples of potential mixing lines. The relatively evolved compositions of both the light 15 
and dark components in banded juvenile scoria of Old Gede (57 wt% and 59 wt% SiO2, 16 
respectively) also suggest that simple binary mixing, at least of these components, is an 17 
unrealistic model for explaining the geochemical variation observed within this group 18 
(mixing line 3, Fig. 11a). Furthermore, distinct plagioclase core compositions (Fig 6) are 19 
observed in similar sized phenocrysts within the dark, more basic component (G11) of the 20 
mingled rocks, indicating that the parental magma to the basic lava may have experienced 21 
mingling and mixing with other magma prior to the clear evidence for magma mingling 22 
observed in G13. Fractional crystallisation trends FC23 and FC20 (see figure caption for 23 
details) and amphibole fractionation (FC Amph) are also incapable of accounting for the 24 
general data array (Fig. 11a). Thus neither fractional crystallisation nor mixing alone is 25 
capable of explaining the chemical evolution of GVC magma. 26 
To investigate the relationship between geochemistry and petrological complexity 27 
GVC samples are classified according to their petrological features e.g. presence of xenoliths, 28 
mantled orthopyroxene, magma mingling and coexistence of olivine and orthopyroxene in 29 
Figs. 11b (La/Nd versus 1/Nd) and c (Ni versus SiO2). Ni versus SiO2 was chosen for its 30 
potential to identify samples with the most evidence for mixing (i.e. similar Ni content over a 31 
wide range in SiO2) from those controlled by fractional crystallisation. Both figures show that 32 
there is no obvious link between indicators of petrological complexity/disequilibrium and 33 
whole-rock geochemical data in GVC lavas and juvenile scoria. 34

In summary, the scatter in major and trace element data preclude control via simple 1 
mixing processes. However, multiple magma mixing and mingling events may play a role in 2 
modifying the chemical composition of magma during magmatic evolution. Geochemical 3 
evolution most likely reflects a combination of fractional crystallisation (of amphibole at 4 
depth and the mineral assemblage observed in the rocks) and magma mixing processes, 5 
where multiple fractionation trends and mixing end-members are required. 6 
 7 
Crustal contamination 8 
There is substantial evidence from island arc volcanoes (Thirlwall and Graham 1984; 9 
Davidson et al. 1987; Ellam and Harmon 1990; Thirlwall et al. 1996; Macpherson et al. 1998; 10 
Handley et al. 2008b) for the contamination of primary magmas by arc crust. Contamination 11 
is also thought to be an important process in the western Sunda arc (Gasparon et al. 1994; 12 
Gasparon and Varne 1998; Chadwick et al. 2007) and responsible for modifying isotope 13 
ratios of lavas at Sangeang Api volcano in the eastern Sunda arc (Turner et al. 2003). 14 
The incorporation of crustal material during crustal differentiation may generate 15 
correlations of isotope ratios with indices of differentiation (e.g. SiO2, Rb) in volcanic rock 16 
data (e.g. Davidson et al. 2005). However, this assumes that the contaminant will have an 17 
isotopic composition distinct from that of magmas ascending from the mantle. Relatively 18 
little is known about the composition of the arc crust in West Java. It is hypothesised that 19 
West Java is built upon pre-Tertiary, continental-type basement (Hutchinson 1989; Metcalfe 20 
1996; Soeria-Atmadja et al. 1998; Hoffmann-Rothe et al. 2001). Hamilton (1979) suggests 21 
that the crust in West Java may consist of relatively immature continental crust, ophiolite 22 
slivers and older volcanic rocks. Crustal contamination involving these materials may be 23 
difficult to detect. Meta-sedimentary/continental-type crustal xenoliths have not been 24 
discovered in any GVC units (only clasts of igneous origin are observed) further highlighting 25 
the difficulty of identifying „crustal‟ contributions in arc lavas. The relatively wide range in 26 
Sr isotope ratios of volcanic rocks from the GVC could be the result of the assimilation of arc 27 
crust. However, there are no clear correlations between Sr and O isotope ratios and SiO2 28 
within the individual eruptive groups (Fig. 9). There is a slight correlation in the data set as a 29 
whole, with the most evolved samples (Older Quaternary) possessing the most primitive 30 
radiogenic isotope compositions and the least evolved rocks (Pangrango) display the least 31 
primitive Sr isotopic compositions (Fig. 9a). The weak correlation observed is the reverse 32 
trend of that expected by the assimilation of continental-type crust during fractional 33 
crystallisation (AFC, DePaolo 1981), which typically generates positive correlations between 34

 A large contrast exists between the low 18O values of the mantle (+5.57  0.32‰, 8

> +10‰, Davidson and Harmon 1989) of upper crustal materials, due to low temperature 10

(Fig. 10a). In Fig. 10b the GVC data generally lie along a mixing curve representing 20

lavas have been contaminated by young or old continental-type material. Ophiolitic material, 23 
i.e. oceanic crust, displays a wide range in oxygen isotope ratios due to interaction between 24 
basaltic rocks and seawater over a wide range of temperatures (Muehlenbachs 1986). 25 
Therefore, if interaction with oceanic basement had been a significant process at GVC we 26 
may predict greater scatter in 18O values than observed. Similarly, a wide range of oxygen 27 
isotope ratios may develop in the mafic to intermediate edifices and roots of Sunda arc 28 
magmatism that pre-dates GVC. 29 
  In summary, mantle-like clinopyroxene 18O values of GVC lavas suggest negligible 30 
input of high 18O crustal rocks during differentiation. Most variation in Sr isotope ratios of 31 
GVC lavas is therefore proposed to arise from variations in source compositions/components. 32

Summary and conclusion  4 
Whole-rock major and trace element compositions within each eruptive series at GVC are the 5 
result of a complex interplay of fractional crystallisation (at variable degrees and depths) and 6 
inferred multiple-mixing events. Mid- to heavy-REE data and an amphibole-bearing xenolith 7 
provide support for significant magmatic differentiation in the mid- to lower crust via 8 
fractional crystallisation involving amphibole. Coexisting pyroxene pairs estimate that 9 
fractionation takes place at temperatures of 891-1046ºC and pressures of 3.4-6.5 kbar, 10 
equivalent to ~13-24km depth beneath the volcanoes. Fractional crystallisation of the mineral 11 
assemblage observed in the rocks (plagioclase + clinopyroxene + titanomagnetite ± olivine ± 12 
orthopyroxene) can largely account for the geochemical variation observed at GVC and most 13 
likely plays a role in modifying the composition (to differing degrees) of each magma batch. 14 
Whole-rock geochemical data are inconsistent with simple (binary) magma mixing processes. 15 
However, multiple mixing events cannot be excluded and may explain the significant scatter 16 
observed in variation diagrams. 17 
 The degree of petrological complexity in GVC volcanic rocks is highly variable 18 
within and between each eruptive group, indicative of complex magmatic histories. No 19 
simple correlation is observed between disequilibrium features in GVC rocks, such as the 20 
degree and type of plagioclase compositional zoning (and the magnitude of plagioclase core 21 
composition variability) and the presence or absence of clinopyroxene overgrowths on 22 
orthopyroxene. The relatively small changes in mol% An observed in compositional zoning 23 
of plagioclase phenocrysts in GVC rocks may be caused by changes in P, T, and PH2O in the 24 
upper crustal magmatic system rather than changes in melt composition. However, banded 25 
juvenile scoria provide strong evidence for the (late-stage) interaction of distinct magmas at 26 
Gede volcano (Young and Old Gede groups) and suggest that magma „mixing‟ may be an 27 
important eruption-triggering mechanism. The relationship between petrological and 28 
geochemical evidence for mixing is not straightforward at GVC. No obvious link is noted 29 
between indicators of petrological complexity/disequilibrium (e.g. presence of xenoliths, 30 
mantled orthopyroxene, magma mingling and coexistence of olivine and orthopyroxene) and 31 
whole-rock geochemical data. For a greater understanding of textural and chemical 32 
relationships in GVC volcanic rocks, and to place better constraints on the importance of 33

mixing processes for magmatic evolution, further study would benefit from high-resolution 1 
major- and trace-element mineral profiling, backscattered electron imaging (e.g. Ginibre et al. 2 
2002) and fine-scale Sr isotope plagioclase profiling (e.g. Davidson and Tepley 1997). 3 
Low, mantle-like clinopyroxene 18O values of GVC lavas suggest negligible input of 4 
high 18O crustal materials during magmatic differentiation. Poor correlation of Sr isotope 5 
ratios with indices of differentiation of GVC rocks precludes significant assimilation of 6 
mature continental-type crust with magma beneath the complex. This contrasts with 7 
conclusions reached by Gasparon et al. (1994) who proposed that the upper-crust is the 8 
dominant source responsible for the „crustal‟ geochemical and isotopic signatures observed in 9 
western Sunda arc lavas. This implies that the relatively thick (compared to East Java) West 10 
Javan arc crust is relatively immature and any deep-seated (shallow contamination is not 11 
consistent with O-isotope data) crustal contamination evades detection probably due to the 12 
similar geochemical characteristics shared by the crust and ascending magma. These 13 
conclusions are consistent with the geochemical characteristics of the crustal contaminant 14 
acting in AFC at neighbouring Salak (Handley et al. 2008a). However, this does not truly rule 15 
out the possibility that continental-type material constitutes part of the crust beneath all of 16 
West Java, just that it is not required to explain the geochemical variation observed in GVC 17 
lavas and volcanic rocks of other West Javan arc-front volcanoes. Instead, stable and 18 
radiogenic isotopes indicate that „crustal‟ geochemical and isotopic characteristics arise in 19 
GVC rocks as a result of contamination of the mantle source. Mantle wedge contamination is 20 
also proposed in studies of other Sunda arc volcanoes (Gerbe et al. 1992; Elburg et al. 2002; 21 
Gertisser and Keller 2003; Handley et al. 2007). Based on correlations of trace element ratios 22 
with strontium isotopes the magmatic source composition of the older geographical units, 23 
Gegerbentang and Older Quaternary, is distinct from the younger eruptives of Pangrango and 24 
Gede volcanoes. 25

Analytical techniques 
Mineral analyses were performed on carbon-coated polished thin sections of selected 
GVC volcanic rocks using a Cameca SX 100 electron microprobe at the University of 
Manchester NERC facility. The accelerating voltage was 15kV and beam current was 
2nA. Detection limits based on counting statistics (wt%) for Al, Mg, K, Ca, Ti are 
0.01 or lower, Na, Si, Cr, Ni are around 0.03, while Fe is slightly higher around 0.08. 
Element precision is dependant on the mineral being analysed but was typically better 
than 1% for Ca, Ti, Si, Al and Mg, between 1-2% for Fe, 2.7% for Ni and around 4% 
for Na, K, Mn and Cr. 
Major element contents of GVC whole-rock samples were determined on 
fused glass discs produced by the Fusion method (spectroflux 105) using the 
Automated Philips PW2404 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer at the University of 
Edinburgh. In-house rock standards were used to calibrate the machine and monitor 
accuracy and precision during analysis. 
Trace element concentrations of GVC rock powders were determined on the 
PerkinElmer ELAN 6000 quadrupole ICP-MS at Durham University following the 
analytical procedure and instrument operating conditions described by Ottley et al. 
(2003). Multiple analyses of procedural blanks (3 per batch), in-house standards and 
international reference materials (W2, BHVO-1, AGV1, BE-N and BIR1) during each 
session e.g. at the start, mid-way and at the end of a run, allowed any drift in the 
instrument calibration to be detected. Reproducibility (internal and external) of 
standard values on the ELAN were better than 5% relative standard deviation. 
Preparation of whole rock powders for Sr isotope analysis was undertaken in 
the Arthur Holmes Isotope Geology Laboratory (AHIGL) at Durham University. The 
separation procedure for Sr follows that detailed by Handley et al. (2008a). Sr isotope 
ratios were determined on the AHIGL ThermoElectron Neptune Multi-collector 
Plasma Mass Spectrometer (MC-ICP-MS).  Details of instrument operating conditions 
are presented in Nowell et al. (2003) and Dowall et al. (2003). Instrumental mass bias 
was corrected for using a 88Sr/86Sr ratio of 8.375209 (the reciprocal of the 86Sr/88Sr 
ratio of 0.1194). Data quality was monitored over several analytical sessions by 
regular analysis of standard reference materials during each run. The reproducibility 
of the 87Sr/86Sr ratios for NBS 987 standard solutions in each of the individual 
analytical sessions is better than 21 ppm in all cases. Blank samples processed (at 
Analytical Techniques

least 2 per sample batch) were analysed by ICP-MS on the PerkinElmer ELAN 6000 
quadrupole at Durham University. Total analytical blanks for Sr were below 1.2 ng 
(typically <300 pg). These values are insignificant considering the quantity of Sr 
processed from the volcanic rocks (30-66 μg). 
Oxygen isotope analyses of mineral separates (~10mg per sample) were 
determined by laser-fluorination at Royal Holloway, University of London using an 
analytical procedure following that of Macpherson et al. (2000). In-house standard 
values of SC olivine 2 and GMG II during the period of study were within 0.01‰ of 
accepted values: +5.24‰ ± 0.04 (1σ, n = 6) and +5.69‰ ± 0.08 (1σ, n = 15), 
respectively. Oxygen yields were slightly low, but consistent over the individual 
sessions: 93% for plagioclase (n = 1), between 92-94% (n = 12) for clinopyroxene and 
between 98-100% for olivine (n = 3). Replicate analyses of plagioclase and 
clinopyroxene throughout the study were within 0.09‰ and 0.04‰ respectively. 
Oxygen results are reported as per mil deviations relative to the standard mean ocean 
water (V-SMOW) standard.

lavas: constraints from unusual minor and trace element variations at Salak 
Volcano, Indonesia. Chem Geol 255:360-376

depleted mantle plume from contrasting 18O/16O ratios of back-arc lavas from 
the Manus Basin and Mariana Trough. Earth Planet Sci Lett 176:171-183. 
Nowell GM, Pearson DG, Ottley CJ, Schweiters J (2003) Long-term performance 
characteristics of a plasma ionisation multi-collector mass spectrometer 
(PIMMS): the ThermoFinnigan Neptune. Plasma Source Mass Spectrometry.

geological samples for the analysis of REE and trace elements via ICP-MS.
